user_message:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of init_response_body_data: ```c static int init_response_body_data (void) { if (0 != body_dyn_size) { body_dyn = (char *) malloc (body_dyn_size); if (NULL == body_dyn) { fprintf (stderr, "Failed to allocate memory.\n"); return 0; } if (tool_params.medium) { /* Fill the body with HTML-like content */ size_t pos; size_t filler_pos; static const char body_header[] = "\n" "\nSample page title\n\n" "\n"; static const char body_filler[] = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
\n"; static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n"; pos = 0; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_header, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header)); pos += MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header); for (filler_pos = 0; filler_pos < (body_dyn_size - (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header) + MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer))); ++filler_pos) { body_dyn[pos + filler_pos] = body_filler[filler_pos % MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_filler)]; } pos += filler_pos; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_footer, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer)); } else { /* Fill the body with binary-like content */ size_t pos; for (pos = 0; pos < body_dyn_size; ++pos) { body_dyn[pos] = (char) (unsigned char) (255U - pos % 256U); } } } return ! 0; } ``` Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_footer, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer)); ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
scenario: No violation: the memcpy call does not call init_response_body_data (neither directly nor indirectly). memcpy is a standard library routine and MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ is typically a macro/compile-time expression, so there is no recursion. A violation would occur only if memcpy or MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ were (re)defined so that they directly or indirectly invoked init_response_body_data (for example, if memcpy were a wrapper that called back into init_response_body_data), which is not the case here.
